entry.title: [CrOS settings] add Passpoint mojom channel to settings UI
entry.content:
Injects the Passpoint mojo channel to network settings UI to prepare the future display of Passpoint information in Wi-Fi network details.

entry.title: Flag guard Camera app integration with holding space.
entry.content:
The holding space service will ignore attempts to add Camera app items to the holding space model when the feature is disabled. Additionally, when the feature is disabled, any persisted Camera app items will be removed during restoration.
Bug: b:275895388 Change-Id: I678922f9e445e7db204641e7fbac21eb65cd86c7 Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4425199 Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Commit-Queue: David Black <dmblack@google.com> Reviewed-by: Angus McLean <angusmclean@google.com> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130807}

entry.title: hid: Passing origin to HidConnectionTracker
entry.content:

entry.title: arc: Update list of extensions supported by ArcFileSystemWatcherService
[Extensions] Apply extension permissions immediately on UI request.
entry.content:
Currently there are multiple scenarios where we apply permissions on a user request in the UI, and popup a bubble with a "Reload" button will occur if the page needs to reload in order to properly apply the permissions change. But a user can dismiss this and select the "Reload this page" button and the permission will not be applied. This can cause confusion especially where a user might want to revoke an extension's permissions and later realized the extension is still running when they do this.
To match this setting change to how other chrome settings apply we'll be applying the permission request immediately on user UI request (instead of deferred to after the "Reload" bubble is accepted) in multiple scenarios:
* On-click in the toolbar (clicking the extension's icon when it wants access) * Changing the permissions from the context menu (bug reporter's scenario) * Allowing multiple extensions active tab permission (similar to #1, but can grant for multiple permissions and is controlled by the ExtensionsMenuAccessControl flag[1])
This now makes it so whether the user clicks the "Reload this page" button or the reload bubble acceptance it makes no difference to the permission being applied.
However, obviously, the page will still need to be reloaded if this is required for the extension to work as expected (run all scripts, block web request going forward, etc.) or to ensure permission is fully revoked in all places. So, as before, an extension can "partially" run meaning non-blocked actions will run while blocked actions will be held back until page reload. An example of this is the Adblock plus extension which will start counting blocked adds in it's badge text, but ads on the page will not be removed since that functionality is a blocked action (probably a script injected on document start).
UI mock ups (google-internal): https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1UA3STu8DqtQ5FumyPX-PwKFgnoCZ9-45t9LUJMOiDkE/
[1]: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:extensions/common/extension_features.cc;l=91-93;drc=1a7cebd3b866379d8955857853102192199c2fc4
Low-Coverage-Reason: reload_page_dialog.cc -- strings-only change to the file.
Bug: 1400812 Change-Id: I54d0e197310382abebd0709cd4e8fe457da4283b Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4320950 Reviewed-by: Christian Dullweber <dullweber@chromium.org> Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Commit-Queue: Justin Lulejian <jlulejian@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130788}

entry.title: Fix leaks and clean up code
entry.content:
Issues addressed:
1. The SecAccessControlRef was leaked in the credential_store.mm code. To fix that, use a base::ScopedCFTypeRef. In the code of secure_enclave_client_impl.mm, it wasn't leaked, but the code was awkward, so this CL pulls it out.
2. The notion that kSecAttrLabel takes a CFString of a particular encoding doesnt make sense; CFStrings do not have encodings. Rewrite all the comments for clarity.
Bug: none Change-Id: I8adb1e32dca0b6ed0cab528288ecd325bb366942 Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4427205 Reviewed-by: Adam Langley <agl@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Adam Langley <agl@chromium.org> Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Auto-Submit: Avi Drissman <avi@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130783}

entry.title: Wire up WebMessageListener ArrayBuffer support with AndroidX boundary
entry.content:
This CL wire up newly added ArrayBuffer type support of WebMessageListener to AndroidX boundary. All changes are still behind feature flags: `WEB_MESSAGE_GET_MESSAGE_PAYLOAD` and `kArrayBufferJsToBrowser` in native.
- Rename feature flag to indicate ArrayBuffer type. The flag is not used in prod (behind DEV suffix). - WebView->AndroidX: Post ArrayBuffer when AndroidX supports the new flag. (Right now JS -> Java ArrayBuffer is behind feature flag). - AndroidX->WebView: Add new 'postMessageWithPayload' method to 'JsReplyProxy', the existing one only accepts string. Same changes in AndroidX are required later.
Test: Build and install WebView on userdbg pixel, run AndroidX webkit tests. ArrayBuffer tests will be added in AndroidX when feature is ready.
Bug: 1374142 Change-Id: I3dbcd714cddc0efb0c1619019f26d2c82d2aa73e Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4297714 Reviewed-by: Peter Pakkenberg <pbirk@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Richard He <linyhe@microsoft.com> Reviewed-by: Bo Liu <boliu@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130770}

[iOS] Don't use UIApplicationMain in ContentShell subprocesses
entry.content:
This CL makes process startup for subprocesses look more like other non-iOS platforms, by skipping UIApplicationMain. This also makes subprocesses behave more similarly to WebKit subprocesses on iOS, which also do not use UIApplicationMain.

entry.title: [GridNG] Add extra margins to a subgridded item's contribution size
entry.content:
1. Introducing fields in `NGGridLayoutTrackCollection` to accumulate the start/end extra margin from subgrids, which will be used to compute the respective extra margin to be added to subgridded items.
Also adding methods to compute the start/end extra margins to be applied to specific track spans within a track collection.
2. Adding the start/end extra margin to a subgridded item's contribution size. This extra margin will accommodate any ancestor subgrid's margin, border, scrollbar, padding, and gutter size.
3. Correcting an invalid definition for `grid-column` in the WPT test `auto-track-sizing-001.html` and its respective reference file.
Bug: 618969 Change-Id: I4c9c1264d91939b35a758afd00e081ed4d7bdb2e Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4421571 Reviewed-by: Alison Maher <almaher@microsoft.com> Commit-Queue: Ethan Jimenez <ethavar@microsoft.com> Reviewed-by: Ian Kilpatrick <ikilpatrick@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130742}

entry.title: Mark promise-rejection-event-during-parse.html as failing
entry.content:
This patch applies the rule for TestExpectations in this test to apply to all platforms since it is being flaky on mac in crbug.com/1433292. There is a baseline file which expects the test to fail in a certain way, and the flake is that we are sometimes deviating from that. This patch removes the expectation file since it isn't useful if we are failing in different ways that produce different expectations. This patch also removes the timeout, pass, and crash expectations because as far as I can see this test never crashes, passes, or times out.
Bug: 1433292, 1225773 Change-Id: I6f9c815511c539dda2eefe3fcafde949cc93ba81 Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4429237 Reviewed-by: Xiaocheng Hu <xiaochengh@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Joey Arhar <jarhar@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130734}

entry.title: [GridNG] Fix incorrect DCHECKs and re-enable baseline tests for subgrid
entry.content:
Fixing a couple of issues that caused crashes after CL:4412832:
1. Allow `ComputeMinMaxSizes` to return the fixed size of the column track collection from its constraint space's `NGGridLayoutSubtree`.
2. Remove the incorrect expectation of the available block size being always definite for subgrids in `ComputeGridGeometry`.
3. Don't DCHECK whenever `baselines_` is not present in a track collection, instead use a default value of `LayoutUnit::Min`.
Bug: 618969 Change-Id: I9f5687def8fba28fbb01166bf951942757d6a2db Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4422414 Commit-Queue: Ethan Jimenez <ethavar@microsoft.com> Reviewed-by: Ian Kilpatrick <ikilpatrick@chromium.org> Reviewed-by: Alison Maher <almaher@microsoft.com> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130721}

entry.title: Invalidation of background-attachment:fixed on inline elements on scroll

entry.title: WebUI: Add presubmit check to enforce consistent naming of test files.
entry.content:
WebUI test files should be named with the "*_test.ts" suffix. Adding a presubmit to prevent a common misnaming of "*_tests.ts". Example error
** Presubmit ERRORS: 1 ** Disallowed '_tests' suffix found in 'chrome/test/data/webui/settings/idle_load_tests.ts'. WebUI test files must end with "_test" suffix instead.
The presubmit check only checks TypeScript files (no JS). All violations have already been fixed in precursor CLs, as discovered by running: git cl presubmit --files="*.ts"

entry.title: Fix resize issue in snapped state
entry.content:
The behaviour of restoring bounds from the window verison history was ambiguous which led to some pretty confusing behaviours. In general, we always want to take the restore bounds from the head of the version history, but we currently also allow for a special case where if the current state is encountered in the history, we will override the current restore bounds.
It seems like this case is a special provision for the minimize to unminimize case, because the restore bounds is overloaded in that case (where the restore bounds is used to store the windows actual bounds). This is problematic when combined with horizontal or vertical maximize which actually relies on the restore bounds to store the "actual" restore bounds.
The code is now restructured with the following rules:
1. We always take the restore bounds from the head of history. 2. If no bounds exists, we clear the restore bounds. 3. If an override is provided, we will ignore the window state history and use that instead. (This is currently only used by minimize atm).
This also fixes a small bug in the pruning logic where we might possibly get an incorrect history chain depending on whether or not we add a new restore state to the history. This is because we did not change what target we used to check whether or restore is possible depending on whether or not we are adding a new restore state.
Fixed: 1427451 Change-Id: Ie70dea56acff896e9bb3912977d7d3579fdc6b48 Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4417085 Reviewed-by: Addison Luh <aluh@chromium.org> Reviewed-by: Xiaoqian Dai <xdai@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Fred Shih <ffred@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130704}

entry.title: Properly handle not provision error after openSession.
entry.content:
MediaDrm.getKeyRequest and MediaDrm.provideKeyResponse may throw NotProvisionedException if the origin needs re-provision. When this happens MediaDrm.openSession will succeed. Since our provision flow is triggered when hitting NotProvisionedException when opening session, this will fail the MediaDrm forever, unless user explicitly triggers licenses cleanup.
In this path, we'll unprovision the origin when this happens. The current MediaDrm instance is still unusable, but the next MediaDrm creation can properly trigger the provision flow.
Bug: internal b/278131999 Test: Play DRM protected content on the device twice, the second playback succeeds.
Change-Id: I61a9ceda80f6a134fd67afa4db63932b97141f9f Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4426232 Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Reviewed-by: John Rummell <jrummell@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Yuchen Liu <yucliu@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130701}

entry.title: Launch calc instead of notepad
entry.content:
Two tests in sbox_unittests have always used notepad as a convenient and harmless child process, however on Windows 11 this becamse more complicated. When c:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe is launched it is redirected to the WindowsApps version of notepad. If this version is not installed then CreateProcessW(..., L"notepad", ...) will fail.
Launching c:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe manually from a command prompt in this scenario will succeed, launching the old notepad, so there appears to be some black magic in the process creation path.
Rather than worrying about the details it is better to remove the dependency on notepad and instead use calc.
Using test_child_process.exe was considered but this is problematic because GetProcessBaseAddress relies on WaitForInputIdle and therefore requires a GUI app as its child process.
A buggy assumption in GetModuleList() was found and fixed as well.
Bug: 1430425 Change-Id: Id655ac578e46da58c64b4d9369855a059a0419de Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4427681 Reviewed-by: Alex Gough <ajgo@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Bruce Dawson <brucedawson@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130688}

entry.title: Two new main-thread scrolling (repaint) reasons
A fragment can only be monolithic if it's the only one.
entry.content:
How can something be monolithic, if the node creates more than one fragment? Then it's fragmented. Not monolithic.
Therefore, only mark a fragment as monolithic if block fragmentation is forced off when at the first (and thus only) fragment.
This replaces the code changes in CL:4422851, which wasn't sufficient, and also introduced some problems on its own. That CL made it so that we wouldn't miss OOF fragments when searching for them during pre-paint. This would cause the code in FragmentPaintPropertyTreeBuilder::UpdatePaintOffset() to act up, when setting the PaintPropertyTreeBuilderFragmentContext:: is_in_block_fragmentation flag. There's a similar check for monolithicness there (but without the non-first-fragment check), and it would just go ahead and treat a non-first fragment of a containing block as monolithic, even though such OOF fragments would be direct descendants of a fragmentainer, which in turn would mess up the paint offset in FragmentPaintPropertyTreeBuilder::SwitchToOOFContext().
The test included would fail without CL:4422851, then fail differently with that CL applied, and now, with this CL, it will pass. :) The test expects the containing block to be split into two fragments, and its second fragment to be pushed below a float that was forced into the second column.
Bug: 1432946 Change-Id: Ia98796f908eba77765294f8ab3e5d6ad4eda5fad Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4420359 Reviewed-by: Alison Maher <almaher@microsoft.com> Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Commit-Queue: Morten Stenshorne <mstensho@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130673}

entry.title: [TabModel] Save tab list after closing tab(s).
entry.content:
When a new tab is created or navigates, both Tab state and tab metadata are updated. However, both are skipped when closing a Tab. In this CL, we persistent Tab metadata file when Tab(s) are closed. This prevents from showing deleted tabs again after relaunching Chrome due to metadata file isn't persistent to disk during shut down. Beside, a kill switch is added for these changes.
Bug: 1416619 Change-Id: Ia8c898df384d8b8bead3f7bcb8da03d65f873191 Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4426709 Code-Coverage: Findit <findit-for-me@appspot.gserviceaccount.com> Reviewed-by: David Trainor <dtrainor@chromium.org> Commit-Queue: Xi Han <hanxi@chromium.org> Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1130658}

entry.title: Replace deprecated SkImageEncoder APIs with new variants
[Thumbnail Cache] Tweaks and Polish
entry.content:
Split ETC1 and JPEG to have separate file task runners. They never use the same file name so there should be no contention.
Also just some "drive-by" improvements while looking over the code.
While working on this CL I attempted to collapse Write and Compress into the same method to avoid thread hoping, but concluded it was worse to do that via benchmarking. Issues arose due to: * Compress time >> Write time so moving compression onto the file_task_runner everything gets a lot slower. * To avoid the above issue it is possible to create a file and pass it to another thread that allows blocking to compress and write all at once. This adds back a thread hop, but is still efficient. However, if something fails the deletion also has to happen on the file_task_runner resulting in two hops and another check. * The prior solution is maginally (7%) faster when there are multiple parallel writes as there is less contention on the file_task_runner. However, this was a benchmark that wrote 1000 small filtes in parallel and in production the ThumbnailCache limits parallel writes to 5 in the ThumbnailCache which makes this benefit minimal (see default_write_queue_size in values.xml). * The above solution also has a problem where an empty file exists for a time which might need to be read. This could be addressed by having the ThumbnailCache track current writes, and defer those reads (something I am considering to remove ETC1 decompression), but this gets complicated quickly.

entry.title: media/gpu/v4l2: MT2T support
[GridNG] Introduce CreateConstraintSpaceForSubgridAlgorithm
entry.content:
Previously we relied on `CreateConstraintSpaceForLayout` to create the constraint space of a subgrid; for subgridded axes, the containing grid area size is forced as its fixed available size, but this might not be correct for standalone axis, where we may need to use a different available size, e.g., when there's a specified width/height.
This was an issue because we want to force the fixed available size for both axes when we size a subgrid's track collections, otherwise we might end up calling `ComputeMinMaxSizes` with no subgridded columns/rows.
This change also introduces `SubtractMarginsFromAvailableSize` to adjust the fixed available space to account for a subgrid's margins.
Baseline tests were regressed due to newly uncovered crashes, which will be addressed in the follow-up CL:4422414.

entry.title: [Extensions] Use BrowserContextID in more places.
entry.content:
This expands the usage of this typedef to the map of rules registries. Since we only use the BrowserContext pointer as a key into this map, using BrowserContextID avoids the chance we might use a dangling pointer.
This also cleans up a few more things:
1. The GetBrowserContextID function is now inline. There is no reason for this to be otherwise, since the compiler will completely optimize out any calls.
2. The implementation of GetBrowserContextID was not compliant with the C standard regarding casting between pointers and std::uintptr_t. The standard states that it is only guaranteed that casting from void* to std::uinptr_t will work, so an intermediate cast to void* is required.
This is a cleanup CL to prepare for breaking up the event router.

entry.title: [omnibox][ml] Remove extra layer in model callbacks, add trace events.
entry.content:
Previously, the ML model finishing would call `ProcessModelOutput()`, which called `OnUrlScoringModelDone()`, which would then call `OnUrlScoringModelDoneForAllMatches()`.
The intermediary callback didn't hold any functionality except passing the output along, so this CL simplifies it by having `ProcessModelOutput()` call the barrier callback directly.
Trace events are also added to the Ml Scoring related functions.

entry.title: Add jcmd to jdk runtime_deps
chromeos: Fix DumpWithoutCrashing during login restart to apply flags
entry.content:
Chrome's flags at the login screen can be set by policy or by the device owner account. If a user signs in to an account with different flags set, chrome restarts to apply the new flags.
This causes a shutdown where the user is signed in, but the primary profile may not be loaded yet. Some shutdown code related to caching the app locale calls ProfileManager::GetPrimaryUserProfile(), which then triggers a DumpWithoutCrashing().
Fix this by avoiding GetPrimaryUserProfile() and instead explicitly checking if the profile exists from BrowserContextHelper.
